sections.title: Early Brain Development
sections.summary:
## 🧠 Brain Structure Formation

**Think of the brain like building a house:**
• **Week 3-4:** Foundation laid - 3 main sections form
  - Forebrain (front rooms) 🏠
  - Midbrain (middle hallway) 🚪
  - Hindbrain (back utilities) 🔧
• **Week 5:** Rooms get subdivided (5 total sections)

## 🤸 Cerebellum Development

**Like a sports coach in your brain:**
• Appears at 6 weeks (tiny!)
• Grows 3x bigger by age 1 📈
• Controls: Physical skills, balance, fear responses
• *Analogy:* As baby learns to crawl/walk, cerebellum grows to match!

## 💓 Medulla Oblongata

**Your body's autopilot system:**
• Forms by 20 weeks
• Controls things you don't think about:
  - Breathing (even while sleeping) 😴
  - Heart beating 💗
  - Blood pressure
  - Sneezing 🤧
• *Like:* Car's automatic systems (AC, engine cooling)

## ⚡ Neural Connections Explosion

**Brain's internet gets built super fast:**
• Birth to 3 years: 700-1000 new connections PER SECOND! ⚡
• Year 1: Brain doubles in size 📏
• Age 3: Reaches 80% adult size
• *Think:* Like building internet cables - more connections = faster thinking
• **Key:** Rich experiences strengthen connections (music, colors, textures)

sections.title: Piaget's Stages of Development
sections.summary:
## 👶 Stage 1: Sensorimotor (0-2 years)

**Like little scientists exploring with their senses:**
• Start with reflexes (sucking, grasping) 🍼
• Learn to control movements
• **Object Permanence (6 months):** "Peek-a-boo!" - understanding things exist even when hidden 🙈
• **4+ months:** Deliberately repeat actions (drop toy, watch it fall, repeat!) 🧨
• By age 2: Know they're separate from the world

## 🎨 Stage 2: Pre-operational (2-7 years)

### Symbolic Function (2-4 years)
**Imagination takes off:**
• **Symbolic Play:** Box becomes car, stick becomes sword 📦→🚗
• **Language:** Words become symbols for things
• **Egocentrism:** Can't see other viewpoints (*"Why can't you see what I see?"*)
• **Animism:** Think toys have feelings 🧸💖

### Intuitive Thought (4-7 years)
**The "Why?" stage:**
• Ask endless questions ❓❓❓
• **Centration:** Focus on one thing only (*taller glass = more water*)
• **Can't Conserve:** Don't understand same amount in different shapes
• **Irreversibility:** Can't mentally "undo" actions

## 📚 Stage 3: Concrete Operational (7-12 years)

**Logic with real objects:**
• **Conservation:** Same amount stays same! 🥤
• **Seriation:** Sort by size, height, etc. 📈
• **Classification:** Group things logically
• **Reversibility:** Can think backwards (*6-2=4, so 4+2=6*)
• **Decentration:** See multiple viewpoints 👀
• Still struggle with abstract ideas

## 🧠 Stage 4: Formal Operational (12+ years)

**Abstract thinking unlocked:**
• Think about thinking 🤔
• Handle multiple variables
• Understand consequences (*"If I don't study, I'll fail"*)
• Hypothetical reasoning (*"What if...?"*)

sections.title: Piaget's Cognitive Development Theory
sections.summary:
## 🧠 Core Concepts

Children actively adapt to their world through building mental **schemas** (plans/patterns about how things work).

Intelligence develops through stages, not just accumulating facts.

## ⚙️ Key Processes

• **Schemas** - Mental frameworks to understand world
  - Example: 'classroom schema' includes desks, board, chairs
• **Assimilation** - Adding new experiences to existing schemas
  - Child calls airplane 'bird' because it flies
• **Accommodation** - Changing schemas when they don't fit
  - Realizing airplanes aren't birds - they're metal, carry passengers
• **Equilibrium** - Mental balance when schemas explain all experiences

## 📈 Development of Intelligence

Built through progressing through stages and creating/modifying schemas.

*Example:* Child's 'bird schema' evolves from 'things that fly' to understanding differences between birds and planes.

## 🎓 Educational Applications

• Discovery learning
• Focus on thinking processes not just right answers
• Acknowledge children think differently than adults
• Individual-paced learning

## ✅ Strengths & ❌ Weaknesses

**Strengths:** Practical applications, generated extensive research, explains how children build knowledge.

**Weaknesses:** Ignored cultural/social influences, subjective interpretations, some studies show children can do things earlier than Piaget thought.

options: When new experiences fit existing schemas

sections.title: Dweck's Mindset Theory
sections.summary:
## 🔒 Fixed vs Growth Mindset

### Fixed Mindset
• Believes abilities are **unchangeable**, innate
• When praised for being 'smart', children think ability is fixed
• Leads to: avoiding challenges, giving up easily, ignoring feedback
• Can cause depression and learned helplessness

### Growth Mindset
• Believes **practice and effort** improve abilities
• When praised for effort, children persist through challenges
• Embrace feedback, learn from failures, inspired by others' success

## 💬 Impact of Praise

• **Person praise** ('You're so smart!') → Fixed mindset
• **Process praise** ('You worked really hard!') → Growth mindset
• Teachers' mindsets affect how they view student potential

## 📈 Research Evidence

• **Mueller & Dweck (1998)** - Ability praise led to fixed mindset and vulnerability to setbacks
• **Yeager & Dweck (2012)** - 1500+ students, low achievers with growth mindset training performed better

## 🎓 Educational Implications

• Focus on praising **effort and strategies**, not intelligence
• Teach that brain can grow and change
• Emphasize learning process over grades
• Help students see mistakes as learning opportunities

## ✅ Strengths & ❌ Weaknesses

**Strengths:** Practical applications, positive theory showing change is possible, research support.

**Weaknesses:** Many studies in artificial lab settings, may oversimplify complex learning factors.

sections.title: Willingham's Learning Theory
sections.summary:
## 📚 Factual Knowledge First

Skills like problem-solving and reasoning require **prior factual knowledge**.

*Example:* Understanding 'she has more likes than me' needs knowledge of social media 'likes'.

Knowledge frees up working memory space for higher-order thinking.

## 🧠 Working Memory

• **Limited capacity** system with separate processing for:
  - Visual information
  - Auditory information
  - Decision-making component
• When facts are automatic, more mental space available for complex thinking

## 💪 Practice and Effort

Essential for mastery - must practice until skills become **automatic**.

*Quote:* 'Don't practice until you get it right, practice until you can't get it wrong.'

Applies to:
• Knowledge (rehearsal → long-term memory)
• Motor skills (muscle memory through repetition)

## 📈 Development Strategies

### Cognitive Development
• Use problems within student ability but requiring effort
• Understand developmental stages but remember abilities vary day-to-day
• Consider factors beyond development (task understanding, motivation)

### Physical Development
• Motor skills improve through **conscious practice** of movement sequences
• Focus on suitable movements, practice in correct order

### Social Development
• Challenges Piaget - believes children can take others' perspectives by **18 months** (not 7 years)
• Strategies: demonstrate appropriate behavior, control impulsive behavior, encourage self-regulation

## ✅ Strengths & ❌ Weaknesses

**Strengths:** Practical applications, draws from multiple areas of cognitive science, experimental support.

**Weaknesses:** Doesn't emphasize individual differences enough, not one testable theory.

sections.title: Three Mountains Study (Piaget & Inhelder, 1956)
sections.summary:
## 🏔️ Background

Tested Piaget's theory that **pre-operational children** (2-7) are egocentric - can only see world from their own viewpoint.

**Concrete operational children** (7+) can 'decentre' and see others' perspectives.

## 🔬 Method

• **100 children** aged 4-12
• Used 1m² model with **3 mountains:**
  - Green (lowest, house on top, winding path) 🏠
  - Brown (middle, red cross, stream) ➕
  - Grey (highest, snow-covered) ❄️
• 10 photographs from different viewpoints
• Wooden doll with no facial features

## 📋 Procedure

Three tasks:
• Use cardboard shapes to show mountain view from different positions
• Choose photographs showing what they/doll could see
• Position doll to match given photograph viewpoint

## 📈 Results

### Pre-operational (4-6.5 years)
• Always chose **their own view**, even when asked for doll's perspective
• Couldn't position doll correctly
• Showed **egocentrism** throughout

### Concrete operational (7+ years)
• Gradually understood others have different views
• By 9-10, could accurately show doll's different perspective
• Could coordinate multiple viewpoints

## 🎯 Conclusion

Supported Piaget's stages - younger children egocentric, older children can **decentre**.

Provided evidence for stage-based cognitive development.

## ✅ Strengths & ❌ Criticisms

**Strengths:** Detailed qualitative data, experimental controls, reliable findings across many children.

**Criticisms:** Other studies with more realistic tasks found children could decentre earlier:
• Borke (1975) - 3-year-olds **79% correct** with Sesame Street character
• Task may have been too abstract/unrealistic for younger children

sections.title: Parent Praise Study (Gunderson et al., 2013)
sections.summary:
## 🏠 Background

Built on Dweck's mindset theory using **natural home settings** instead of artificial lab experiments.

Previous research showed praise type affects children's beliefs about ability and effort.

## 🗣️ Person vs Process Praise

### Person Praise
*'You're so smart!'*
• Praising the individual → Entity theory (abilities are fixed)
• → **Fixed mindset** → Less likely to try hard on difficult tasks

### Process Praise
*'You worked really hard!'*
• Praising behavior/effort → Incremental theory (abilities can change)
• → **Growth mindset** → More likely to persist and improve

## ♀️♂️ Gender Differences

Previous studies suggested:
• **Boys** receive more process praise → incremental theory
• **Girls** receive more person praise → entity theory
• May explain some gender differences in academic persistence

## 🔬 Method

• **Longitudinal study** following 53 children (29 boys, 24 girls)
• From 14-38 months old
• Participants: 64% white, 17% African-American, 11% Hispanic, 8% multiracial
• Parents didn't know praise was being studied
• Recorded **natural parent-child interactions** at home
• Five years later, measured children's motivational frameworks

## 🎯 Aims

• Test if natural parental praise affects children's later reasoning
• Examine if parents give different praise types to boys vs girls
• See if early praise predicts later motivational beliefs

## 🌿 Ecological Validity

**Major strength** - used natural home environment rather than artificial lab setting.

Provides more realistic understanding of how praise actually affects children.

## 📚 Connection to Education

Supports teaching parents and teachers to focus praise on **effort and process** rather than innate ability or intelligence.
